para.phrase: PAUL E. KILGORE AND TOM COENYE

sect2.title: TAXONOMY
sect2.para: The generaBordetella, Achromobacter, Alcaligenes, Kerstersia, Advenella, and Paenalcaligenes belong to the family Alcaligenaceae (order Burkholderiales in the Betaproteobacteria) (1).

The genusBordetella contains 15 species: Bordetella avium, B. bronchialis, B. bronchiseptica, B. flabilis, B. hinzii, B. holmesii, B. muralis, B. parapertussis, B. pertussis (the type species), B. petrii, B. pseudohinzii, B. sputigena, B. trematum, B. tumbae, and B. tumulicola (2–6). Other putative species, such as “B. ansorpii,” and other strains similar to B. trematum have been described but not validly named. B. pertussis, B. parapertussis, and B. bronchiseptica could be considered a single species, but chemotaxonomic differences and differences in host range and pathogenesis (2, 7) support their status as separate species. Analysis of their genome sequences reveals that B. parapertussis and B. pertussis are independent derivatives of a B. bronchiseptica-like ancestor (7). The taxonomy of the genus Achromobacter is closely intertwined with the genus Alcaligenes. The genus Alcaligenes is now limited to Alcaligenes aquatilis, A. faecalis (the type species), A. pakistanensis, and A. endophyticus, while the genus Achromobacter consists of 20 species: Achromobacter aegrifaciens, A. agilis, A. aloeverae, A. animicus, A. anxifer, A. deleyi, A. denitrificans, A. dolens, A. insolitus, A. insuavis, A. kerstersii, A. marplatensis, A. mucicolens, A. pestifer, A. piechaudii, A. pulmonis, A. ruhlandii, A. spanius, A. veterisilvae, and A. xylosoxidans (the type species) (3, 6, 8–14). In addition, this genus contains several yet-unnamed genogroups (15). The genus Kerstersia was proposed for a set of strains phenotypically resembling A. faecalis; this genus contains two species (Kerstersia gyiorum and K. similis) (8). Similarly, the genus Advenella was created to harbor a number of Alcaligenes-like strains; these strains belong to Advenella alkanexedens, A. faeciporci, A. incenata, or one of several unnamed genomic species (16, 17) or were previously described as Tetrathiobacter species (17). Finally, the genus Paenalcaligenes contains three species (Paenalcaligenes hermetiae, P. hominis, and P. suwonensis) (18).

sect1.title: Bordetella
sect1.para: The genome sizes of members of this genus ranges from 3.7 Mbp to 5.3 Mbp (4.086 Mbp forB. pertussis, 4.774 Mbp for B. parapertussis, 5.338 Mbp for B. bronchiseptica, 5.287 Mbp for B. petrii, 3.732 Mbp for B. avium, and ~3.8 Mbp for B. holmesii). Insertion sequences are mainly found in the genomes of B. pertussis (IS481 and IS1002), B. parapertussis (IS1001), and B. holmesii (IS481 and IS1001-like) and less often in B. bronchiseptica (7, 20, 21). A comparison between the species reveals that only around 50% of the genome is conserved in all species and that multiple mechanisms, such as gain or loss of genes, point mutations, and horizontal gene transfer, may play a role in the development of the species (22). Analysis of virulence genetic changes demonstrates that specific changes in O antigens, protein secretion systems, and bacterial toxins are occurring across Bordetella clades, species, and strains and that these changes may lead to alterations in the genes encoding for pertussis vaccine components (23).

Bordetellae are catalase positive and oxidize amino acids, but no carbohydrates are fermented. Some species possess uniformly distributed flagella and are motile. Bordetellae are generally able to grow in simple synthetic media under aerobic conditions (exceptB. petrii; see below). However, B. pertussis and B. parapertussis are sensitive to toxic substances and metabolites present in many microbiological media and need special transport conditions, special culture media, and prolonged incubation. The other species can be isolated by routine microbiological procedures.

B. petrii is the most versatile Bordetella species; it can grow aerobically and anaerobically and was initially found as a free-living environmental bacterium (21). All other bordetellae are found only in warm-blooded animals and humans. B. avium is a pathogen of poultry and has only once been isolated from humans. B. bronchiseptica can cause respiratory infections in many animal species and infrequently in humans. B. holmesii is recognized as a pathogen mostly in immunosuppressed individuals but also in immunocompetent patients and may cause a variety of systemic diseases in various organ systems (24, 25). B. ansorpii, B. hinzii, B. petrii, and B. trematum rarely cause human infections and are mainly reported in immunocompromised patients. B. parapertussis has been found in sheep and humans, while B. pertussis is thought to be strictly a human pathogen (Table 1).

table.title: TABLE 1 Members of the genus Bordetella

sect1.para: Bordetellae express several virulence factors controlled by a complex virulence expression system operating in response to environmental conditions (BvgAS) (2, 26), changing between mode X (respiratory tract infection), mode I (intermediate, possibly relevant for transmission), and mode C (starvation). Virulence factors can be classified as adhesins, autotransporters (e.g., filamentous hemagglutinin, fimbriae, and pertactin), and toxins (e.g., pertussis toxin [PT], adenylate cyclase hemolysin, and lipopolysaccharide) (2). Only B. pertussis produces PT, encoded by the ptx gene, whereas B. parapertussis and B. bronchiseptica contain the ptx gene but normally lack the promoter (2). PT has ADP-ribosyltransferase activity and ribosylates G(i) proteins, thereby suppressing chemotaxis, oxidative responses, and the overall activity of neutrophils and macrophages. Filamentous hemagglutinin is a large (220-kDa) surface-associated and -secreted protein and mediates the adhesion of the bordetellae to the ciliated epithelium of the upper respiratory tract. Filamentous hemagglutinin is produced by B. pertussis, B. parapertussis, and B. bronchiseptica (2). Type 2 and 3 fimbriae (FIM2 and FIM3) are important factors in colonizing the respiratory mucosa. Isolates of B. pertussis can display FIM2, FIM3, or both on their surfaces. Adenylate cyclase hemolysin is a hemolysin with enzymatic activity (27). B. pertussis also produces a lipopolysaccharide without a repetitive O-antigenic chain. Pertactin is a 68- to 70-kDa surface protein that mediates eukaryotic cell binding in vitro (2), is involved in cell attachment, and is highly immunogenic (28). Notably, in recent years, isolates not expressing pertactin have been found in many countries with increasing frequency. The clinical presentation appears similar for pertactin-positive and -negative strains (29–31). B. pertussis, B. parapertussis, and B. bronchiseptica share virulence genes as well, including those encoding the type III secretion system and the Bordetella-secreted protein regulator (BspR), a conserved protein across species (32).

sect1.title: Achromobacter
sect1.para: Achromobacter species are Gram-negative, nonsporulating, small bacilli. Most species are motile, but motility is weak or absent in A. pulmonis and is strain dependent in A. insuavis. Achromobacter species are strictly aerobic and nonfermentative, although strains of some species are able to grow anaerobically with nitrate as an electron acceptor (10). All Achromobacter species are oxidase and catalase positive, but none of them exhibit DNase, lysine decarboxylase, ornithine decarboxylase, arginine dihydrolase, or gelatinase activity (9–11, 13). Urease activity was reported only in A. aloeverae. Achromobacter species grow well on simple media, and colonies on nutrient agar are flat or slightly convex with smooth margins and range from white to light brown (9). Under laboratory conditions, growth occurs between 30 and 37°C and in the presence of 0 to 1.5% NaCl (9, 10, 33). Several Achromobacter species contain the Q-8 ubiquinone system (1). Although detailed information about the natural habitat of these organisms is lacking, soil and water are considered the primary sources of infection (1).

sect1.title: Alcaligenes, Kerstersia, Advenella, and Paenalcaligenes
sect1.para: Following many taxonomic revisions, the genusAlcaligenes is now limited to A. faecalis (with three subspecies: A. faecalis subsp. faecalis, A. faecalis subsp. parafaecalis, and A. faecalis subsp. phenolicus), A. aquatilis, A. endophyticus, and A. pakistanensis. A. faecalis subsp. parafaecalis, A. faecalis subsp. phenolicus, A. aquatilis, A. endophyticus, and A. pakistanensis are represented by environmental isolates only. Some A. faecalis strains produce a characteristic fruity odor and/or cause a greenish discoloration of blood agar medium; these strains were previously referred to as “A. odorans.” Alcaligenes species are Gram-negative, strictly aerobic rods or coccobacilli that possess oxidase and catalase activity (1). Cells are motile by means of 1 to 12 uniformly distributed flagella. The optimum growth temperature is between 20 and 37°C. They grow well on simple media, and colonies on nutrient agar are generally nonpigmented.

Cells ofKerstersia and Advenella species are Gram negative, small (1 to 2 μm), and rod-shaped or coccoid and occur alone, in pairs, or in short chains. Motility is strain dependent. They grow well on simple media. On nutrient agar, colonies are flat or slightly convex with smooth margins and range from white to light brown. They are strictly aerobic and nonfermentative. All isolates studied so far are catalase positive, while none exhibit β-galactosidase activity (8, 16). Kerstersia strains can grow between 28 and 42°C; growth also occurs with up to 4.5% NaCl. Predominant fatty acids in Kerstersia species are C16:0 and C17:0 cyclo (8). Advenella strains can grow at between 30 and 37°C and at NaCl concentrations between 0 and 3%.

Cells fromPaenalcaligenes species are Gram-negative, small (1- to 2-μm) rods. They grow well on nutrient agar at 25 to 30°C and are oxidase positive. Sugars and sugar-related compounds are not utilized.

sect1.title: B. pertussis and B. parapertussis
sect1.para: B. pertussis and B. parapertussis are transmitted via respiratory droplets, and for B. pertussis in susceptible contacts, the transmission rate may approach 90% with an infectious dose as low as 100 CFU (2). B. pertussis has shown to occur more frequently during the summer and autumn months in the United States, Germany, and the Netherlands (34, 35). In Australia, studies of seasonal variation suggest pertussis peaks have occurred from late winter to early summer (36). In addition, although data from tropical and subtropical areas are more limited, surveillance reports from Senegal and Kenya suggest that B. pertussis transmission may be higher during cooler, dry months of the year (34). The bacteria attach to ciliated cells lining the nasopharynx and subsequently colonize the upper respiratory tract. B. pertussis and B. parapertussis are the cause of pertussis, or whooping cough. Infections by B. parapertussis tend to take a milder clinical course with a shorter duration of coughing and less vomiting and whooping than that of B. pertussis (2, 37–40). Globally, among children less than 5 years of age, pertussis is estimated to cause 24.1 million hospitalizations and 160,700 deaths each year, with the largest proportion of these occurring in Africa (41). It is assumed that the disease is grossly underreported due to underrecognition by clinicians, underuse of diagnostic testing, infected patients not seeking medical attention, and limitations in disease reporting through surveillance systems (42). B. pertussis also continues to circulate in populations where high vaccination coverage of infants and children is achieved, because the protection after natural infection and vaccination wanes after several years (39, 43).

B. parapertussis causes a whooping cough-like illness, and recent data suggest that current pertussis vaccines may elicit cross-protective antibodies against B. parapertussis in infants and children (44). In vaccinating countries, cases of pertussis are now mainly observed in neonates, unvaccinated young infants, older schoolchildren, adolescents, and adults (38, 39, 43, 45, 46). A permanent carrier state is not found in pertussis, although in outbreak situations asymptomatic transient carriage of Bordetella DNA detected by PCR has been observed (2, 40). In vaccinated European populations, the basic reproduction number was estimated to be 5.5 (47), and transmission mainly occurs from adolescents and adults to infants or among older vaccinated children, adolescents, and adults (2, 38). Neonates and young infants are at greatest risk of being infected by their parents, although casual contacts may be important (48). In various countries, such as Australia, Brazil, the United States, and the United Kingdom, significant increases in notified cases have occurred in recent years, and various factors (e.g., structural changes in circulating strains, waning immunologic protection after immunization with acellular vaccines, low vaccine coverage, changes in vaccination schedules, more effective diagnostics, and differences in immunologic priming) have been hypothesized as being responsible for the outbreaks (49, 50). Several countries have implemented pertussis immunization during pregnancy, and reports suggest that such programs may reduce pertussis rates, hospitalizations, and mortality among infants (51–53).

sect1.title: Other Bordetella Species, Achromobacter, Alcaligenes, Kerstersia, and Advenella
sect1.para: Among the bordetellae,B. holmesii (5, 24) is increasingly found mainly by PCR tests primarily using IS481 as a target, which shares homogeneity between B. pertussis, B. holmesii, and other bordetellae (Tables 2 and 3) (54, 55).

Data on epidemiology and transmission are limited toAchromobacter infections in cystic fibrosis (CF) patients. Persistent infections with A. xylosoxidans can occur, because genotypically identical isolates are recovered from the respiratory tract over prolonged periods of time (56–59). There have been several reports of multiple CF patients being colonized or infected by the same A. xylosoxidans isolate (57–61). Both patient-to-patient transmission and acquisition from the environment have been proposed as explanations for the spread of certain strains among CF patients (58, 62). The “Danish epidemic strain” was identified as A. ruhlandii (63). This strain has infected multiple patients in two Danish CF centers, and cross-infection was documented to also occur by indirect patient-to-patient contact (64).

sect1.title: B. pertussis and B. parapertussis
sect1.para: After a typical incubation period of 7 to 10 days (range, 4 to 28 days), the primary infection starts with rhinorrhea, sneezing, and nonspecific coughs (catarrhal phase). Clinical signs and symptoms of pertussis are found in primary infections of nonvaccinated children, with coughing spasms, audible whooping, and vomiting (paroxysmal phase) (39, 65). Cases in neonates and unvaccinated young infants often present with apnea as the only clinical sign (2, 43, 66). In older schoolchildren, adolescents, and adults, clinical signs and symptoms can vary widely. Adult pertussis may be associated with an acute cough (i.e., <3 weeks in duration) or subacute cough (3 to 8 weeks) in which clinicians should assess the four characteristics of paroxysmal cough, posttussive vomiting, inspiratory whooping, and absence of fever when ruling in or out a clinical diagnosis of pertussis (67). Even in the absence of paroxysms, a cough with a duration of more than 3 weeks should lead to suspicion of pertussis. Coughing is frequently accompanied by choking, vomiting, and whooping (38). The U.S. CDC/CSTE (Council of State and Territorial Epidemiologists) surveillance case defines pertussis (https://ndc.services.cdc.gov/case-definitions/pertussis-2020/) by the presence of a cough lasting ≥2 weeks with at least one of the following signs or symptoms: paroxysms of coughing, inspiratory whoop, posttussive vomiting, and apnea (with or without cyanosis). Confirmatory laboratory evidence is determined by isolation of B. pertussis from a clinical specimen or positive PCR for B. pertussis. The disease is most dangerous in infants, and most hospitalizations and deaths occur in this age group. Fatal cases of the disease may go undetected in young infants (43, 68). Pertussis-like symptoms may also be caused by adenoviruses, respiratory syncytial virus, human parainfluenza viruses, influenza viruses, Mycoplasma pneumoniae, and other agents (43, 69).

sect1.para: aPos, positive; neg, negative.

sect1.title: Other Bordetella Species
sect1.para: Due to more frequent diagnosis,B. holmesii (5, 70) is suspected to be a pathogen that may cause respiratory symptoms in adolescents and adults (54, 55) and inflammation in various organs in immunocompromised patients. Cases of a pertussis-like illness caused by B. holmesii have been reported from all over the world (25, 55, 71). In a study from Spain, the prevalence of B. holmesii infections increased from 3.9% in 2015 to 8.8% in 2016 (71). B. bronchiseptica, B. petrii, B. avium, B. ansorpii, and B. hinzii are rarely isolated from respiratory materials from patients with respiratory symptoms. In many cases, patients are systemically or locally immunocompromised. As with other Gram-negative nonfermentative bacilli, cases of bacteremia, septicemia, and other invasive manifestations have been described. Other species are less often reported. B. trematum has been isolated from poultry industry workers, and there are recent case reports from patients with lung cancer (respiratory tract) (72) and with congestive dermatitis (leg wound) (73); B. ansorpii has been reported as a rare cause of septicemia. B. petrii and possibly other environmental bordetellae are rarely found in clinical material, and B. avium has so far been isolated only once from respiratory material from humans.

sect1.title: Achromobacter
sect1.para: ManyAchromobacter species have been recovered from clinical samples or from the hospital environment. A. xylosoxidans is an opportunistic human pathogen capable of causing a wide range of infections, such as bacteremia, meningitis, pneumonia, and peritonitis (74, 75). It has also been found to be involved in nosocomial infections attributed to contaminated disinfectants, dialysis fluids, saline solution, and water (76). A. piechaudii has been isolated from various clinical samples, including pharyngeal swab, nose, wound, blood, and chronic ear discharge (77). A. denitrificans (previously known as A. xylosoxidans subsp. denitrificans) has been recovered from many clinical specimens, such as urine, proctoscopy specimens, prostate secretions, the buccal cavity, pleural fluid, and eye swabs, but there are no detailed reports about its clinical significance. A. insolitus (in a leg wound and in urine) and A. spanius (in blood) have been found in clinical material, but their significance is unclear (9). Strains of A. aegrifaciens, A. animicus, A. anxifer, A. dolens, A. insuavis, A. marplatensis, A. mucicolens, and A. pulmonis have mainly been recovered from sputum of CF patients, but their clinical significance remains unclear (10, 11).

Achromobacter spp. are frequently associated with CF. A. xylosoxidans isolates have been reported from CF patients since 1985, and prevalence rates in CF were estimated to range from 3 to 18% (62, 78–80). However, recent studies based on multilocus sequence analysis and/or sequencing of the nrdA gene indicate that patients with CF are often infected with Achromobacter species other than A. xylosoxidans (11, 63, 81, 82). Among 341 Achromobacter species-infected CF patients in the United States, 42% were infected with A. xylosoxidans, and a retrospective analysis (for the period from 1984 to 2013) revealed that 50% of Achromobacter-positive patients attending a Canadian CF clinic were colonized with A. xylosoxidans (83). A high prevalence of A. xylosoxidans (38% and 36%) was also reported in two studies on Danish Achromobacter species-infected CF patients (84, 85) and in studies involving CF patients from France (62) and the United Kingdom (86). Other Achromobacter species frequently recovered from CF patients include A. insuavis, A. dolens, A. ruhlandii, and A. aegrifaciens.

A. xylosoxidans infections in CF patients do not seem to have a significant impact on lung function (60, 78, 87). A recent study indicated that overall, Achromobacter species infections are associated with increased risk of pulmonary exacerbations, but this does not seem to affect long-term prognosis (83). However, infection with the A. ruhlandii Danish epidemic strain can lead to deterioration of lung function (64), and colonization with A. ruhlandii was found to be associated with increased risk of chronic infection (85).

sect1.title: Alcaligenes, Kerstersia, Advenella, and Paenalcaligenes
sect1.para: A. faecalis strains have been isolated from a wide range of clinical samples, but the accuracy of the identification (especially in older reports) is difficult to assess. A. faecalis was found in cases of bacteremia following surgery or cancer treatment, from ocular infections, from a pancreatic abscess, from infections following bone fractures, from urine, and from ear discharge (77). There are sporadic reports of the recovery of A. faecalis in sputum of CF patients (88). K. gyiorum was isolated from human feces, leg wounds, sputum, urine, and chronic ear infections (8, 73), while K. similis was isolated from leg wounds and a neck abscess (89). A. incenata has been recovered from human sputum (including sputum from CF patients) and blood, and several unnamed Advenella species were isolated from similar sources (16). The two P. hominis strains described so far were recovered from blood and urine (18).

sect2.title: COLLECTION, TRANSPORT, AND STORAGE OF SPECIMENS

sect1.title: B. pertussis and B. parapertussis
sect1.para: Clinical sample collection for culture and PCR testing may be challenging depending on the patient’s age and clinical condition, yet the collection technique can significantly impact test sensitivity. Nasopharyngeal (NP) aspirates are optimal samples for collection among infants and young children, and for culture, they are more sensitive than swabs (http://www.cdc.gov/pertussis/clinical/diagnostic-testing/specimen-collection.html; https://www.ecdc.europa.eu/en/publications-data/guidance-and-protocol-use-real-time-pcr-laboratory-diagnosis-human-infection). In older children, adolescents, and adults, posterior NP swabs provide valid specimens and are better than throat swabs. NP swabs should be taken by gently inserting the swab into the posterior nasopharynx under the inferior nasal choana, and the nose of the patient should be slightly bent upward. If possible, two NP swabs should be taken (one for culture and one for PCR), but one swab (to be used for culture and PCR) is also acceptable (https://www.cdc.gov/pertussis/clinical/diagnostic-testing/specimen-collection.html). Swabs should be small and made of Dacron or rayon. Flocked nylon swabs, which are more convenient for the patient, may also be used but have not been validated for B. pertussis PCR or culture. Cotton-tipped or calcium-alginate swabs and swabs with aluminum shafts should not be used for PCR testing because they may inhibit PCRs (90). Samples should be collected prior to initiation of antibiotic treatment (91).

For NP aspirates or swabs, transport time is critical, and a transport medium protecting the bacteria from drying is required. Usual bacteriological transport media, such as Casamino Acids or Amies medium with charcoal, may be used, but transport time should not exceed 48 h. Half-strength Regan-Lowe (RL) charcoal-blood medium may also be used for transport, and it serves as enrichment forB. pertussis.

For PCR, swabs can be transported dry at ambient temperature. The use of microbiological transport media, such as Amies medium with charcoal, does not interfere with PCR (91). Other respiratory samples, such as sputum samples and throat washes, are less suitable (2).

sect1.title: Other Bordetella Species, Achromobacter, Alcaligenes, Kerstersia, Advenella, and Paenalcaligenes
sect1.para: For other bordetellae, normal microbiological transport media seem suitable for transport. Similarly,Alcaligenes, Kerstersia, Advenella, and Paenalcaligenes species can survive in a wide range of environments and at various temperatures. Standard collection, transport, and storage techniques are sufficient to ensure recovery of these organisms from clinical specimens, contaminated nosocomial sources, and the environment.

sect1.title: Nucleic Acid Detection
sect1.para: PCR is 2- to 6-fold more sensitive than culture, depending on the patients’ age, vaccination status, and duration of symptoms. Real-time PCR formats offer a result within several hours instead of several days (91–93). Block-based and real-time PCR provide comparable sensitivity (91, 94, 95). The sensitivity of PCR decreases as cough duration increases; however, due to higher sensitivity of PCR, it may be a useful tool for diagnosis in patients with up to 4 to 6 weeks of coughing (91, 93). In outbreak situations, PCR may detect pertussis transmission among household contacts with very few or no symptoms (96). DNA extraction may be necessary to limit inhibition of PCR (91). Commercially available extraction kits seem to be comparable and appropriate (91), but no head-to-head comparison has been done. Some of these kits are FDA cleared and/or CE marked for this purpose. Multicopy targets for detection are IS481 (copy number, ~200 per cell in B. pertussis) (38, 93), which is present in B. pertussis, B. holmesii, and some B. bronchiseptica strains; IS1001 (copy number, ~20 per cell in B. parapertussis) (97), which is present in B. parapertussis; and IS1002, which is present in B. pertussis and B. parapertussis. The combined use of the three ISs has been suggested to distinguish clinically relevant Bordetella species (98) and to distinguish B. holmesii (99). In current isolates, the number of ISs remained stable compared to those in the sequenced type strains (97). Monogenic targets include the PT promoter (ptxA-Pr), the PT gene, the recA gene from B. holmesii, and the filamentous hemagglutinin and the porin gene. Targets are summarized in Table 2 (91–93, 98–101).

Tests detecting single-copy genes are, however, consistently less sensitive than IS481-based PCRs. Detection can be performed using a sequence-specific approach with fluorescence resonance energy transfer hybridization probes, TaqMan probes, and molecular beacons and also by non-sequence-specific formats using SYBR gI (91). For specificity reasons, most laboratories use sequence-specific formats, and duplex or triplex PCRs for clinically relevant Bordetella species have been developed. Multiplex PCRs for the detection of various respiratory agents, including Bordetella species, are also available but are mostly based on IS481 as the sole target (55). External quality control programs have been implemented in the United States and European countries (94, 102). Apart from contamination problems in laboratories, pseudo-outbreaks of pertussis have also been reported due to swabs contaminated with Bordetella-DNA from clinic environmental surfaces and from vaccines (103).

sect1.title: Direct Fluorescent-Antibody Staining
sect1.para: Direct fluorescent-antibody staining (DFA) on NP swabs or aspirates to detectB. pertussis or B. parapertussis is rapid and simple but lacks adequate sensitivity and specificity; for this reason, DFA is not recommended (2). DFA methods have largely been supplanted by nucleic acid amplification techniques, which offer greater sensitivity and specificity. Other stains have no role in pertussis diagnosis.

sect1.title: B. pertussis and B. parapertussis
sect1.para: Although culture is thought to be almost 100% specific, PCR has mostly replaced it in routine diagnosis (91). Detailed information on culture procedures is contained in previous editions of this Manual (104). In brief, various culture media, such as RL medium, Bordet-Gengou medium, and Stainer-Scholte medium, can be used for culturing B. pertussis and B. parapertussis. Most media are supplemented with cephalexin to suppress concomitant bacterial growth. Cultures should be incubated for at least 1 week at 35 to 37°C in ambient atmosphere. The sensitivity of culture depends on the patients’ symptom duration, age, and vaccination status, with a range from <1% in adolescents and adults with more than 3 weeks of coughing to ~60% in young unvaccinated infants with a few days’ duration of symptoms (104).

sect1.title: Other Bordetella species, Achromobacter, Alcaligenes, Kerstersia, Advenella, and Paenalcaligenes
sect1.para: Bordetella species other than B. pertussis and B. parapertussis from clinical material are encountered as Gram-negative nonfermentative bacilli in the laboratory. Information about their growth characteristics and some biochemical reactions that may be used can be found in Table 4.

Achromobacter species can be isolated from clinical samples by the use of simple media and a selective enteric medium such as MacConkey agar. It has been reported that a minority of A. xylosoxidans isolates grow on Burkholderia cepacia selective oxidative-fermentative-polymyxin B-bacitracin-lactose agar or Pseudomonas cepacia agar (30% and 20%, respectively) but do not grow on B. cepacia selective agar (105). However, data from the U.S. Cystic Fibrosis Foundation B. cepacia Research Laboratory and Repository (J. J. LiPuma, unpublished data) and a previous study (106) indicate that the majority of A. xylosoxidans strains (~60%) grow on B. cepacia selective agar.

sect1.title: B. pertussis and B. parapertussis
sect1.para: In culture,B. pertussis colonies become visible after 3 to 7 days of incubation, while B. parapertussis colonies are visible after 2 to 3 days. On RL medium, colonies are very small, round, and domed and appear silvery. B. parapertussis colonies are larger and less shiny. The minute colonies on Bordet-Gengou medium have a small zone of beta-hemolysis. B. pertussis is a small coccoid Gram-negative rod which is catalase and oxidase positive (B. parapertussis is oxidase negative). Their identity in pure culture can best be confirmed by agglutination with specific antibodies (https://assets.publishing.service.gov.uk/government/uploads/system/uploads/attachment_data/file/861059/ID_5_di+.pdf). Basic biochemical characteristics are given in Table 4. Due to the fastidious growth of B. pertussis and B. parapertussis, commercial systems for Gram-negative rods do not reliably identify both species. For identification, 16S rRNA gene PCR/sequencing may also be employed (107). Matrix-assisted laser desorption ionization–time of flight mass spectrometry (MALDI-TOF MS) is now used in many hospital clinical laboratories to identify a range of bacterial pathogens. While several Bordetella species are included in databases of FDA-cleared MALDI-TOF MS platforms (e.g., B. pertussis, B. bronchiseptica, and B. parapertussis) not all species are present, and studies on the applicability of MALDI-TOF MS for the identification of Bordetella species are scarce. A recent study suggests that MALDI-TOF MS can be used to distinguish B. pertussis, B. parapertussis, and B. bronchiseptica (80, 108), but more data are required before this identification approach can be recommended for routine identification.

table.title: TABLE 4 Useful characteristics for differentiating clinically relevant Bordetella speciesa

sect1.para: aSymbols and abbreviations: +, ≥90% of the strains are positive; −, ≤10% of the strains are positive; (+), variable growth; V, 10 to 89% of the strains are positive; ND, not determined.
bOthers comprise B. bronchialis, B. flabilis, B. sputigena, and B. pseudohinzii.

Isolates ofB. pertussis and, happens less often, those of B. parapertussis can undergo a phase change (109), and if strains have to be stored, storage should be done from primary cultures; these should be frozen in glycerol at −70°C or in a sucrose/bovine serum albumin medium.

sect1.title: Other Bordetellae
sect1.para: Colony morphology is not discriminative for other bordetellae, and the bacteria are small coccoid rods that are catalase positive. In most instances, a biochemical system for identification of Gram-negative bacilli is used, such as API20-NE, Vitek (BioMérieux, Marcy-l’Etoile, France), MicroScan (Siemens, Eschborn, Germany), Phoenix (Becton Dickinson, Franklin Lakes, NJ) (110), or others. These systems were validated for nonfermentative rods, among which a few Bordetella species were evaluated. Overall, the specificity of these biochemical systems for these bacteria is not very high, and for the API20 NE and Vitek II systems, it has been proposed that 16S rRNA gene PCR/sequencing be performed if the results of the biochemical identification are not reported as “excellent” or “very good” (110). 16S rRNA gene PCR/sequencing and ribotyping, as well as MALDI-TOF MS, offer more reliable identification results, and these tests are available in hospital clinical and reference laboratories (80, 111–113). Apart from B. bronchiseptica, the isolation of other bordetellae from clinical samples is a rare event, and their identification should be confirmed by a reference laboratory to avoid misidentification (114).

sect1.title: Achromobacter
sect1.para: Achromobacter species typically show very limited action on carbohydrates (9–12), which hampers the accurate identification at the genus level based on biochemical characteristics, and 16S rRNA gene sequence analysis is recommended for this purpose. Likewise, the increased taxonomic diversity and considerable intraspecies diversity observed in this genus make species-level differentiation based on phenotypic characteristics virtually impossible. A PCR assay (based on the 16S rRNA gene) was developed for A. xylosoxidans, but positive results may also be obtained with strains of other Achromobacter species as well as with some Bordetella species (115). MALDI-TOF MS has been used successfully to identify A. xylosoxidans (80, 116) and reportedly allows the separation of A. xylosoxidans, A. ruhlandii, A. insolitus, and A. spanius (117), although in other studies, species-level identification of Achromobacter spp. with MALDI-TOF MS turned out to be not straightforward (118, 119). In addition, Desai et al. (120) noted that strains identified as A. xylosoxidans by phenotypic tests were commonly identified as A. ruhlandii by MALDI-TOF MS. It should be noted that many of the studies referenced above were published prior to the description of additional diversity within the genus Achromobacter and with older versions of databases. More recent work showed that MALDI-TOF MS distinguishes all Achromobacter species (121) and can even distinguish between epidemic clones of A. xylosoxidans and A. ruhlandii (122). Nevertheless, accuracy of identification based on the default (commercially available) MALDI-TOF MS databases is sometimes low (122).

All establishedAchromobacter species can be separated using concatenated nusA, eno, rpoB, gltB, lepA, nuoL, and nrdA sequences (10, 11, 15), and many studies have confirmed that most species can be distinguished based on sequence analysis of the nrdA gene alone (12, 62, 85, 86, 123).

sect1.title: Alcaligenes, Kerstersia, Advenella, and Paenalcaligenes
sect1.para: ForAlcaligenes, Advenella, Kerstersia, and Paenalcaligenes, 16S rRNA gene sequence analysis is recommended for accurate identification at the genus level. Members of the genus Advenella can be separated from related species by their inability to assimilate phenyl acetate. Kerstersia strains are oxidase negative. K. gyiorum and K. similis can be distinguished based on the oxidation of D-galacturonic acid and D-glucuronic acid (positive in K. gyiorum, negative in K. similis) and D-serine (negative in K. gyiorum, positive in K. similis). A distinguishing characteristic of A. faecalis isolates is that they reduce nitrite but not nitrate. P. hominis cannot assimilate citrate.

sect2.title: TYPING SYSTEMS
sect2.para: B. pertussis and B. parapertussis show limited genomic heterogeneity (37), but some polymorphic regions, such as the toxin gene (ptx), the toxin promoter (ptxP), the pertactin gene (prn), and others, have undergone changes whose cause is not totally clear (124, 125). Expression of fimbriae undergoes temporal changes, possibly influenced by vaccine coverage (125). Nucleic acids of circulating isolates of B. pertussis have been typed by an array of methods, such as conventional and next-generation sequencing (29, 125), pulsed-field gel electrophoresis, variable number of tandem repeat analysis or multilocus variable-number tandem repeat analysis (126, 127), restriction fragment length polymorphism (91), single nucleotide polymorphism (SNP) typing (128), real-time PCR (129), and others (111). Other methods use the proteome as a distinguishing parameter (115). Depending on the problem in question, different typing methods may be employed, and the results can mostly not be compared directly. Conventional multilocus sequence typing (MLST) approaches show low discriminatory power, but a recently developed whole-genome MLST (wgMLST) scheme yielded results in concordance with whole-genome SNP typing and allowed accurate resolution of outbreak and sporadic cases (130). Similar typing methods have been used for isolates of B. holmesii (24).

Typing ofA. xylosoxidans isolates with pulsed-field gel electrophoresis of fragments obtained after digestion with XbaI, SpeI, or DraI has been used in several studies (60, 63, 131) and is reported to have high discriminatory power; data from a recent study suggest that the discriminatory power of pulsed-field gel electrophoresis is higher than that of MLST (62). Randomly amplified polymorphic DNA PCR (58) and PCR with enterobacterial repetitive intergenic consensus or repetitive extragenic palindromic primers (61) have also been used. Two MLST schemes can be used to type all named Achromobacter species (15, 132).

sect1.title: B. pertussis and B. parapertussis
sect1.para: Serologic assays for pertussis can be used for diagnostic confirmation and testing of specimens in the context of a suspected outbreak. When the serologic test is used at a single point in time, specimen collection is optimally performed 2 to 8 weeks after cough onset, when antibodies toB. pertussis are expected to be highest. Specimens may also be collected up to 12 weeks after cough onset (133) (https://www.cdc.gov/vaccines/pubs/surv-manual/chpt10-pertussis.html). Enzyme-linked immunosorbent assays or bead-based assays to quantify anti-PT antibody levels are recommended diagnostic techniques (134–136) that can be performed with paired (acute- and convalescent-phase) or single serum samples. Paired-sample serology is the optimal method of serologic diagnosis (137), but single sample serology also provides good sensitivity and specificity to determine cases in older children, adolescents, and adults (134, 138, 139). A WHO reference preparation for human pertussis serology is available (140), and quantitative results in pertussis serology should be reported in international units per milliliter. For single-sample serology, IgG anti-PT antibodies below 40 IU/ml are not indicative of recent contact, whereas levels above 100 IU/ml can be used as an indicator of recent contact with the bacteria (135, 141–143). Anti-PT IgG antibodies are primarily measured, and anti-PT IgA may serve as an additional test for equivocal results (>40 IU/ml and <100 IU/ml). The measurement of IgM antibodies as well as other methods, such as immunoblotting, complement fixation, agglutination, and others, are not recommended (135). Serology is unable to detect infection with B. parapertussis and cannot distinguish between vaccine- and infection-induced immunological responses (symptomatic or asymptomatic infection) to B. pertussis (135, 142, 144). Commercial serological assays vary in their analytic and clinical accuracy and must be calibrated to a reference standard (144, 145). Pertussis serology cannot be reliably interpreted for 1 year after vaccination with acellular vaccines (135). External quality control programs for pertussis serology are available (145).

sect1.title: B. pertussis and B. parapertussis
sect1.para: B. pertussis and B. parapertussis demonstrate in vitro susceptibility to a range of antibiotics, including some penicillins, macrolides, ketolides, fluoroquinolones, tetracyclines, chloramphenicol, and trimethoprim-sulfamethoxazole, whereas they are resistant to most oral cephalosporins (2). Notably, in China, there is evidence of macrolide resistance (mediated by a mutation in the macrolide binding domain of the 23S rRNA gene) among B. pertussis strains (146–149) and this resistance has been reported in other countries as well (150, 151). In contrast to other bacterial diseases, the exact relationship between the pharmacokinetics and pharmacodynamics of these antibiotics and bordetella in vitro susceptibility is unknown. Furthermore, the effect of antibiotic treatment on the severity or duration of pertussis symptoms is not well documented (43, 152).

Current methods for antibiotic susceptibility testing ofB. pertussis and B. parapertussis are not standardized. If testing is done, the methods include macro- and microbroth dilution, agar dilution methods, breakpoint methods, and the Etest, whereas the disk diffusion method is mostly not feasible (43). Erythromycin resistance may be evaluated by the disk diffusion method, using RL (charcoal agar supplemented with defibrinated horse blood) medium without antibiotics and employing a 15-μg erythromycin disk. Routine antibiotic susceptibility testing of B. pertussis isolates is not recommended and should be done only when special clinical or epidemiological circumstances are encountered (43). Continued surveillance of B. pertussis isolates should also include antimicrobial susceptibility testing.

sect1.title: Other Bordetellae
sect1.para: B. bronchiseptica possesses a β-lactamase (153) and is resistant to many penicillins and cephalosporins and mostly resistant to trimethoprim-sulfamethoxazole (154). A study of canine and feline isolates (155) showed that most isolates are susceptible to amoxicillin-clavulanic acid, tetracycline, gentamicin, and one fluoroquinolone class compound. B. avium was resistant to cefuroxime, trimethoprim-sulfamethoxazole, and tetracycline and susceptible to ampicillin, mezlocillin, and gentamicin (154). Antimicrobial susceptibility testing of other bordetella isolates should be reported in accordance with the reporting for other infrequently isolated and fastidious nonfermentative Gram-negative rods. In these cases, in vitro resistance does not necessarily reflect clinical ineffectiveness.

sect1.title: Achromobacter
sect1.para: Resistance is frequently observed inAchromobacter isolates (156–161), and A. xylosoxidans isolates are typically susceptible only to imipenem, piperacillin, ticarcillin-clavulanic acid, ceftazidime, and trimethoprim-sulfamethoxazole (156, 159). Aminoglycosides, extended-spectrum cephalosporins other than ceftazidime, and quinolones show no activity (156). The majority of the strains are resistant to conventional tobramycin concentrations, but 41% of the strains are inhibited by the higher tobramycin concentrations achievable by aerosol delivery of the antibiotic (156). Similarly, 92% of strains are inhibited by high doses of colistin (100 or 200 μg/ml) (157). The most active combinations of antibiotics include chloramphenicol-minocycline, ciprofloxacin-imipenem, and ciprofloxacin-meropenem (157), as well as combinations with trimethoprim-sulfamethoxazole or tobramycin (160). A. xylosoxidans is resistant to azithromycin and clarithromycin, and only modest synergistic and/or additive activities were observed when azithromycin was combined with meropenem or trimethoprim-sulfamethoxazole (158). These data correlate well with many smaller clinical studies and case reports.

Antimicrobial susceptibility data for otherAchromobacter species are rare, but A. spanius and A. insolitus are resistant to most fluoroquinolones, macrolides, and cephalosporins tested (9), while a blood isolate of A. piechaudii is resistant to ampicillin, cefpodoxime, and gentamicin but susceptible to all other antibiotics tested (162). More than 90% of Achromobacter species isolates recovered from Danish CF patients are resistant to amikacin, ciprofloxacin, and tobramycin, and particularly high MICs were recorded for aztreonam (>256 μg/ml) and fosfomycin (>1,024 μg/ml) (163). The lowest MICs were observed for meropenem (94% of isolates were susceptible), piperacillin-tazobactam (all isolates were susceptible), and trimethoprim-sulfamethoxazole. Colistin (MIC90 = 8 μg/ml) and ceftazidime (MIC90 = 24 μg/ml), two antibiotics commonly used for inhalation therapy, exhibited good activity (163). In a recent study, no meaningful differences in MIC were found between A. xylosoxidans and A. insuavis strains (161). Like many other bacteria, Achromobacter species readily form biofilms in vitro, and biofilm-grown cells showed markedly reduced susceptibility to many antibiotics, with biofilm-inhibitory concentrations higher than the achievable aerosolized concentrations (164, 165). Nevertheless, several strains showed MICs and biofilm-inhibitory concentrations that were below the achievable aerosolized concentrations for levofloxacin and tobramycin (165).

sect1.title: Alcaligenes, Kerstersia, Advenella, and Paenalcaligenes
sect1.para: A. faecalis is more susceptible to antibiotics than A. xylosoxidans. Most A. faecalis strains are resistant to amoxicillin, ticarcillin, aztreonam, kanamycin, gentamicin, and nalidixic acid, while they are susceptible to the combination of amoxicillin or ticarcillin with clavulanic acid, to various cephalosporins, and to ciprofloxacin (166). Most Kerstersia isolates are susceptible to ciprofloxacin and cefotaxime (8), although two more recently described isolates are ciprofloxacin resistant (167). Recent clinical isolates were found to be susceptible to cefepime, gentamicin, and trimethoprim-sulfamethoxazole (167, 168), and a recent K. gyiorum leg wound infection was successfully treated with meropenem (73). Antimicrobial susceptibility in Advenella and Paenalcaligenes species has not yet been studied.

sect2.title: EVALUATION, INTERPRETATION, AND REPORTING OF RESULTS
sect2.para: The usefulness of diagnostic methods in pertussis and parapertussis cases is dependent on the duration of symptoms (Fig. 1). Due to their sensitivity and speed, nucleic acid amplification tests are the preferred method for the direct detection of B. pertussis and B. parapertussis (169). Suggestions for the interpretation and reporting of real-time PCR results are given in Table 3.

If culture is performed, isolation ofB. pertussis or B. parapertussis suggests infection, although the sensitivity is sufficiently high only in neonates and unvaccinated infants. Routine antimicrobial susceptibility testing of isolates is not necessary. Culture remains necessary for surveillance of circulating B. pertussis and B. parapertussis isolates but is not typically performed in clinical laboratories.

Serological diagnosis of pertussis is usually based on single-sample serology collected 2 to 8 weeks following the onset of cough symptoms. Results cannot be correctly interpreted for about 1 year after vaccination with acellular pertussis vaccines. IgG anti-PT levels of ≥100 IU/ml are indicative of recent contact. In adolescent and adult populations, IgG anti-PT levels of <40 IU/ml may be interpreted as not indicative of recent infection (135). Except in Massachusetts, serology is not accepted as a confirmation of cases in the United States. Many European countries with statutory notification and laboratory confirmation accept serology as proof of infection.

Similar to other rarely isolated Gram-negative nonenteric rods, the clinical relevance of species belonging to the generaAchromobacter, Alcaligenes, Kerstersia, Advenella, and Paenalcaligenes from clinical material should be discussed on a case-by-case basis between the microbiology laboratory and the clinician. Antimicrobial testing of these species should be performed and can be helpful in guiding therapeutic decisions.
